title: Perpetual Virginity
intro: Hypothesis: Mary, the mother of Jesus, remained a virgin even after giving birth.

evidence.head: Brothers and Sisters
evidence.short: Jesus is said to have had brothers and sisters.
evidence.details:
Critics point out that Jesus's "brothers" and "sisters" are explicitly mentioned, and some of them are named. This suggests that Mary may have had more children after Jesus.

Proponents argue that these are Jesus's relatives, and usually raise one or both of the following possibilities: 1) They are Joseph's children from a previous marriage, making them Jesus's legal brothers. 2) They are Jesus's cousins (or similar), and calling them "brothers" is just common in Jewish (and many other) cultures.

evidence.head: The "Until" Clause
evidence.short: There is no mention of Mary's virginity after Jesus’s birth, and Matthew 1:25 says they did not have sexual relations "until she had given birth to a son".
evidence.details:
Critics point to "until", which could indicate that the previous statement was true before, but not after the "until" clause.

Proponents argue that "until" doesn't always indicate a change like that, and that Matthew's point is not to comment on Mary's sex life, but to point out that Jesus fulfilled the prophecy in Isaiah 7:14.

bible.text: 25and didn’t know her sexually until she had given birth to her firstborn son. He named him Jesus.
14Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign. Behold, the virgin will conceive, and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel.

evidence.head: Protoevangelium of James
evidence.short: The Protoevangelium of James, also called the Infancy Gospel of James (c. 150 AD), implies Mary's perpetual virginity.
evidence.details:
Proponents cite this as evidence in favour by pointing out that this is a very early document that says St. Joseph was old and already had sons, which means the "brothers" mentioned in the Gospel accounts would be stepbrothers, not maternal half-brothers, and Mary is distraught when she considers the possibility of conceiving the way other women do, suggesting she intended to remain a virgin.

Critics argue that this is unreliable Christian fanfiction at best, and was condemned by the Church according to the Gelasian Decree.

evidence.head: Tertullian and Mary as Bride
evidence.short: Tertullian says Mary became a mother before she became a bride.
evidence.details: Tertullian does not explicitly discuss the idea of Mary's perpetual virginity, but in three works, he makes passing comments that may relate to it. He mentions that Mary became a mother before she became a bride; he argues against the Docetists that Jesus indeed had a real body, and had the mother and brethren to prove it; and he calls Mary a "virgin and wife of one husband". Critics bring up Tertullian as an early ecclesiastical writer who did not seem to think Mary remained a virgin, which suggests this idea may be a later development. Since Sts. Joseph and Mary were already husband and wife when Jesus was born, the only way for Mary to subsequently "become a bride" would be to consummate the marriage. The brethren of the Lord being mentioned also weighs in favour of this interpretation. Proponents argue that both of Tertullian's supposed denials are vague inferences rather than outright statements, and they could be understood differently. When Tertullian calls her "not-virgin", he is referring to the fact that she gave birth and thus would not be "intact" anymore (since his point is that Jesus was actually born of a woman), and he doesn't call Jesus's brethren Mary's children, so they could just as easily be stepchildren or Jesus's cousins. These writings are also all considered to be from Tertullian's Montanist period, and he is known to have held eccentric views on some issues anyway. Finally, Tertullian's comment in On Monogamy seems to suggest she remained a virgin, because he calls her a "virgin and wife of one husband" as if they are both true at once. Critics answer that the comment about her being a wife of one husband could mean she was both at once at the moment of birth, and does not necessarily imply she remained a virgin afterwards. At the very least, it suggests that the idea of perpetual virginity was not universally held at the time.

ancient.summary: On the Flesh of Christ, Chapter 23 (Suggests they consummated the marriage after Jesus's birth)
ancient.author: Tertullian
ancient.text: "She bore which did bear: and if as a virgin she conceived, in her child-bearing she became a wife. For she became a wife by that same law of the opened body, in which it made no difference whether the violence was of the male let in or let out: the same sex performed that unsealing. (...) For all other women marriage opens it. Consequently, hers was the more truly opened in that it was the more shut. Indeed she is rather to be called not-virgin than virgin, having become a mother by a sort of leap, before she was a bride."

ancient.summary: Against Marcion, Book IV, Chapter 19 (Does not explicitly call them Mary's children)

If because they wished to know whether he had been born, or not—had there ever been any doubt of this, which they could resolve by means of that temptation?"

ancient.summary: On Monogamy, Chapter 8 (Could suggest she remained a virgin)
ancient.author: Tertullian
ancient.text: "And indeed it was a virgin, about to marry once for all after her delivery, who gave birth to Christ, in order that each title of sanctity might be fulfilled in Christ's parentage, by means of a mother who was both virgin, and wife of one husband."

evidence.head: Origen's Affirmation
evidence.short: Origen (3rd century) affirms Mary's perpetual virginity.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that Origen is sometimes at odds with other fathers, and probably ended his life in schism.

Proponents argue that Origen's position is usually orthodox, even though he later had a falling out with the Church.

evidence.head: Athanasius's Affirmation
evidence.short: St. Athanasius of Alexandria (4th century) affirms Mary's perpetual virginity.
evidence.details:
Critics point out that the 4th century is rather late to be a reliable witness to a teaching that is not explicit in the New Testament.

Proponents argue that St. Athanasius is known for his staunch defense of Christian orthodoxy and so is a good indication for what came before him.

evidence.head: Ambrose's Affirmation
evidence.short: St. Ambrose of Milan (4th century) affirms Mary's perpetual virginity.
evidence.details:
Critics point out that the 4th century is rather late to be a reliable witness to a teaching that is not explicit in the New Testament.

Proponents argue that St. Ambrose shows that the teaching was widespread geographically even before the 4th century itself.

evidence.head: Jerome's Defense
evidence.short: St. Jerome (4th century) defended Mary's perpetual virginity against Helvidius.
evidence.details:
Critics point out that the 4th century is rather late to be a reliable witness to a teaching that is not explicit in the New Testament.

Proponents argue that St. Jerome's strong defense of this doctrine indicates it was firmly held long before it was handed down to him.

evidence.head: Epiphanius's Defense
evidence.short: St. Epiphanius of Salamis (4th century) defended Mary's perpetual virginity against the Antidicomarians
evidence.details:
Critics point out that the 4th century is rather late to be a reliable witness to a teaching that is not explicit in the New Testament.

Proponents argue that St. Epiphanius's defense indicates that this doctrine was firmly in place even before it was handed down to him.

evidence.head: Liturgical Ever-Virgin
evidence.short: Mary was called “ever-virgin” in both Eastern and Western liturgies by the 4th century.
evidence.details:
Critics point out that the 4th century is rather late to be a reliable witness to a teaching that is not explicit in the New Testament.

Proponents argue that the liturgy was the very centre of Christian life, and did not change as easily as individuals changed their minds, which indicates that the teaching was more ancient.

evidence.head: Marginalized Protests
evidence.short: Contrary opinions are mostly known through rebuttals (e.g. Helvidius).
evidence.details:
Critics argue that the fact that this teaching won out could mean that contrary opinions were widespread, but are simply not preserved, except in rebuttals.

Proponents argue that it could also simply mean that there was a strong consensus in favour.

evidence.head: Vow of Virginity
evidence.short: Mary was surprised that she would bear a son.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this suggests she was expecting to remain a virgin, which is very unusual for a married woman and suggests she may have taken a vow of virginity, as laid out in Numbers 30. The Protoevangelium of James also supports this, since it has her in the Temple for 12 years, and she is distraught when told she will conceive.

Critics argue that Mary may simply have been surprised because she was a virgin when told about the son she would bear. There is no mention of a vow in the Gospel accounts, so that is speculative.

bible.text: 26Now in the sixth month, the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a city of Galilee named Nazareth, 27to a virgin pledged to be married to a man whose name was Joseph, of David’s house. The virgin’s name was Mary. 28Having come in, the angel said to her, “Rejoice, you highly favored one! The Lord is with you. Blessed are you among women!” 29But when she saw him, she was greatly troubled at the saying, and considered what kind of salutation this might be. 30The angel said to her, “Don’t be afraid, Mary, for you have found favor with God. 31Behold, you will conceive in your womb and give birth to a son, and shall name him ‘Jesus.’ 32He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his father David, 33and he will reign over the house of Jacob forever. There will be no end to his Kingdom.” 34Mary said to the angel, “How can this be, seeing I am a virgin?” 35The angel answered her, “The Holy Spirit will come on you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. Therefore also the holy one who is born from you will be called the Son of God. 36Behold, Elizabeth your relative also has conceived a son in her old age; and this is the sixth month with her who was called barren. 37For nothing spoken by God is impossible.” 38Mary said, “Behold, the servant of the Lord; let it be done to me according to your word.” Then the angel departed from her.

YHWH will forgive her. 9“But the vow of a widow, or of her who is divorced, everything with which she has bound her soul shall stand against her. 10“If she vowed in her husband’s house or bound her soul by a bond with an oath, 11and her husband heard it, and held his peace at her and didn’t disallow her, then all her vows shall stand, and every pledge with which she bound her soul shall stand. 12But if her husband made them null and void in the day that he heard them, then whatever proceeded out of her lips concerning her vows, or concerning the bond of her soul, shall not stand. YHWH will forgive her. 13Every vow, and every binding oath to afflict the soul, her husband may establish it, or her husband may make it void. 14But if her husband says nothing to her from day to day, then he establishes all her vows or all her pledges which are on her. He has established them, because he said nothing to her in the day that he heard them. 15But if he makes them null and void after he has heard them, then he shall bear her iniquity.” 16These are the statutes which YHWH commanded Moses, between a man and his wife, between a father and his daughter, being in her youth, in her father’s house.

evidence.head: Mary as the Ark of the New Covenant
evidence.short: Mary is presented as the antitype of the very holy Ark of the Covenant.
evidence.details:
Proponents generally hold to the principle that the New Testament antitype is always greater than the Old Testament type, best illustrated by the old Adam in Genesis vs. the new Adam in Jesus Christ. They point to several parallels between the old Ark of the Covenant and Mary:
- The power and glory of God is said to "overshadow" (ἐπισκιάζω, episkiazō) both.
- St. Elizabeth and David's questions parallel each other.
- St. Elizabeth calls loudly, as did the people transporting the Ark.
- St. John the Baptist leaped in the womb, King David leaped and danced.
- Mary and David both went to Judah.
- Mary and the Ark both waited for three months before returning home.

Critics argue that this is all very speculative and never explicitly pointed out.

Proponents answer that the parallels are too obvious to need pointing out — more so than many of the parallels the New Testament authors themselves draw.

evidence.head: This Gate Must Remain Shut
evidence.short: Church Fathers cite Ezekiel 44:2 as evidence for perpetual virginity.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that applying this to Mary is speculative.

Proponents argue that it is hard to miss the parallels in this chapter.

bible.text: 2YHWH said to me, “This gate shall be shut. It shall not be opened, no man shall enter in by it; for YHWH, the God of Israel, has entered in by it. Therefore it shall be shut.
